titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alex Harris photographs and papers, 1970-2015 RL.10060
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet, Tanner Capps, Michael Shumate

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Alex Harris is a documentary photographer, author, and professor emeritus at the Center for Documentary Studies in Durham, North Carolina. The subjects in the over 600 black-and-white and color photographs that span his career include the landscapes and peoples of Alaska, the American South and New Mexico, and Cuba; subjects in other documentary projects include portraits of older reading volunteers and students in Philadelphia, students on strike at Yale University, counter-culture people at a Rainbow Gathering in Arizona, a boy tethered to electronic technology, elderly people living on their own; and the interior of author Reynolds Price's home. The gelatin silver and inkjet prints range in size from 8x10 inch reference prints to 24x36 inch exhibit prints. Harris's professional papers document his collaborations with other photographers and writers on books and exhibitions, including anthropologist Gertrude Duby Blom, naturalist E.O. Wilson, and South African photographers; they also cover his long career at Duke University, as teacher, author, and co-founder of the Center for Documentary Studies and its publication, DoubleTake. In addition to the paper records, there are many recorded oral histories and interviews. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are organized in project series: The Last and First Eskimos; Southern Color; North Carolina; The Idea of Cuba; Game Boy; May Day, 1970: Yale on Strike; Red White Blue and God Bless You: A Portrait of New Mexico; New Mexico in Black and White; River of Traps (New Mexico); Rainbow Gathering; Philadelphia Experience Corps; Old and On Their Own; and Dream of a House. Harris's professional papers are arranged in these series: Publicity and Audiovisual Materials; Correspondence; Doubletake Files; Project Files; Teaching Materials; and Proof Prints.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The over 600 black-and-white and color photographs in the collection date from Harris's earliest photographic work as a graduate student at Yale University, to his more recent work documenting the American South. The subjects range widely, and include the landscapes and peoples of Alaska, the American South and New Mexico, and Cuba; they also include portraits of older reading volunteers and students in Philadelphia, students on strike at Yale University, counter-culture people at a Rainbow Gathering in Arizona, a boy going about his day, tethered to electronic technology, elderly people living on their own in central North Carolina, and views of the art-filled interiors of author Reynolds Price's home. The gelatin silver and inkjet prints range in size from 8x10 inch reference prints to 24x36 inch exhibit prints; for large prints there are smaller viewing copies to facilitate research access.

The remaining series house Harris's papers, which document collaborations with other photographers and writers, including Gertrude Duby Blom and E.O. Wilson, and South Africa photographers; they also document his career at Duke University as a teacher, author, and co-founder of the Center for Documentary Studies (CDS) and its serial publication, DoubleTake. The Publicity and Audiovisual Materials Series contains recordings of lectures as well as publicity for exhibits and publications. The Correspondence Series includes not only Harris's exchanges with other photographers, friends, and professionals, but also grant applications, research notes, drafts and proofs, print materials, and some photographs. The DoubleTake files consist mainly of materials generated during the planning stages and early years of the magazine's existence. Materials on Harris's extensive collaborations on other publications, documentary projects, and related exhibitions make up the large Project Files Series, which includes many oral histories and interviews related to his projects, mostly on cassette tapes (use copies must be made for access). The Teaching Materials Series comprises syllabi, student writings and slides, and other materials from classes taught by Harris mainly through the CDS at Duke University. Finally, the Proof Prints Series contains a small number of proof prints related to various projects.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Alex Harris is a photographer, writer, and teacher. Born in Atlanta, Georgia, he has spent most of his adult life in North Carolina. He has photographed for extended periods in Cuba, the Inuit villages of Alaska, the Hispanic villages of northern New Mexico, and across the American South. He is professor emeritus of the Practice of Public Policy and Documentary Studies at Duke University. At Duke, Harris is a founder of the Center for Documentary Photography (1980), The Center for Documentary Studies (1989), DoubleTake magazine (1995), and The Lewis Hine Documentary Fellows Program (2002) His awards include a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Fellowship in Photography, a Rockefeller Foundation Humanities Fellowship, and a Lyndhurst Prize. Harris's work is represented in major photographic collections, including the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, the North Carolina Museum of Art in Raleigh, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. His photographs have been exhibited widely, including two solo exhibitions at the International Center of Photography in New York City. As a photographer and editor, Harris has published eighteen books, among them A World Unsuspected: Portraits of Southern Childhood (North Carolina, 1987), River of Traps: A New Mexico Mountain Life (New Mexico, 1990), with William deBuys, which was a finalist for the 1991 Pulitzer Prize in general non-fiction, The Idea of Cuba (New Mexico, 2007), and Why We Are Here: Mobile and the Spirit of a Southern City (Liveright/Norton, 2012), with Edward O. Wilson. Dream of a House: The Passions and Preoccupations of Reynolds Price (GFT/CDS, 2017) and Where We Find Ourselves: The Photographs of Hugh Mangum, 1897â€“1922, (University of North Carolina Press, CDS, 2019) both with Margaret Sartor.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Due to the vulnerability of very large digital prints, full sets of smaller viewing prints (11x17 inches) are available in the Cuba Auto/Landscapes, Game Boy, and Mobile series, and should be used whenever possible. Please contact the Rubenstein Library for access to the original prints.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Some listening copies are available and are noted in this guide. Use of other materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use this material.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection are made available for research, scholarship, and private study. Copyright has not been transferred to Duke University. For reuses of this material beyond those permitted by fair use or otherwise allowed under the Copyright Act, please consult https://library.duke.edu/rubenstein/research/citations-and-permissions

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Selected images from this collection have been digitized and are available online as part of Duke Digital Collections.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Alex Harris photographs and papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as gifts and purchases from 1992 to 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alex Harris Photographs and Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Alex Harris's work in South Africa with fellow documentarians Bruce Payne, Paul Weinberg, Margaret Sartor, and Omar Badsha, and his work with Gertrude Duby Blom in Central America, is represented in the following collections, also held in the Rubenstein Library:

unittitle.label: Collection
unittitle.extref: South Africa Documentary Photographs Collection, 1940s-2007 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These black-and-white photographs have as their subjects Eskimos and Inuit elders and their day-to-day lives in small Alaskan communities. The images were taken over the course of multiple trips over a five-year period in the 1970s in villages along the Kobuk River, located above the Arctic Circle, and in fishing villages along the southern coast of the Bering Sea in Alaska. The project provided documentary images for a study conducted by Robert Coles, supported by the non-profit Commonwealth Fund, and published in the book, The Last and First Eskimos (1978). Consists of 50 11x14 inch prints, and six 16x20 inch prints, all in gelatin silver format. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains 38 24x30 inch color images taken in Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, North Carolina, and South Carolina. Photographed from 1984-1985, the subjects are small towns and cities, with their modest houses, gas stations, parking lots, tobacco warehouses, malls, storefronts, usually unpopulated but with old cars and trucks often appearing in the frame. Many of the locations are in Durham, North Carolina; other cities include (but are not limited to) Wilmington, Wake Forest, and Norlina, North Carolina; Birmingham, Alabama; Monroe, Bastrop, and Raysville, Louisiana; Summerton, St. Helena's Island, and Charleston, South Carolina; and Hinesville, Sunbury, and Stone Mountain, Georgia. The project was funded by an award from the Lyndhurst Foundation. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Representing some of Harris's earliest work, this project was an initiative of the Institute of Policy Sciences and Public Affairs at Duke University and started as a photographic study of substandard housing and living conditions in the state. Featured are portraits of North Carolinians and scenes from rural locations from counties in the eastern, central and western regions. There are portraits of people of all ages and races, and are shown in front of their dwellings; working, chiefly at agricultural tasks; and relaxing by pitching horseshoes. A number of them are of migrant workers. Fifty-six black-and-white 17x22 inch digital prints.

In 1972, a selection of these photographs was exhibited at University of North Carolina Symposium on the South, "The Mind of the South and The Southern Soul" as well as at the Southeastern Center for Contemporary Art. In 1978, ten of these photographs were also published in I Shall Save One Land Unvisited by Jonathan Williams, and were part of a traveling exhibition opening at the Corcoran that same year.
Eleven other exhibit prints, printed in 2015 for the exhibition "Where We Live: A North Carolina Portrait," are housed in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series comprises 21 24x30 inch pigmented inkjet prints and one 24x30 type C lambda digital laser color print of Cuban landscapes and city scenes taken by Harris in the 1990s. The photographs were shot through the interior windshields of classic American cars dating from 1948-1958.

Scenes include views of wide boulevards, seafronts, worker's housing, and storefronts. Also includes one image, photographed in 2003 and used on the cover of the book by the same name, of a woman posing in her living room. Titles assigned by photographer.
A full set of 22 viewing prints is available and preferred for research access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series of color photographs features the artist's son, Will, playing his Game Boy in a variety of public, private, and natural settings. The project took shape from the artist's observation in the 1990s that children were becoming increasingly attached to hand-held, portable electronic gaming devices; it explores the implications of how pre-adolescent interaction with electronics might bear out on post-adolescent human interaction and relationships. Smaller reference copies for the 22 large 20x24 inch inkjet prints are available and are preferred for research access. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alex Harris's earliest work in the collection consists of 12 black-and-white 16x20 inch digital prints of student demonstrations at Yale University. The demonstrations came in response to the arrest of Black Panther Party leader, Bobby Seale, who was accused of ordering the murder of a supposed police informant in New Haven. The series documents the demonstrations from a variety of angles and includes images of National Guard soldiers, students, and university officials. These images remained unprinted for almost 37 years until they were published as part of a Duke University exhibition of Harris's early work. Titles assigned by photographer.

Red White Blue and God Bless You: A Portrait of Northern New Mexico

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After a shoot in New Mexico in the 1970s, Harris returned there in the 1980s, visiting familiar locations in the High Road area he had photographed earlier. Specific locations include Chamisal, El Valle, Las Trampas, Las Vegas (NM), PeÃ±asco, Rio Lucio, Truchas, and Vallecito. Scenes include snow on the high plains, horses, towns and streets, and people of various ages. One series of images was taken on the Picuris Native American reservation. Other images feature the colorful interiors of houses, which offer a glimpse into the intimate spaces and folk culture of the inhabitants. Some outdoor locations such as nightclubs and streets are viewed through a car windshield, foreshadowing images from the trip to Cuba in 1998. Digital pigmented color prints measure 20x24 inches, with the exception of two 16x20 prints, and were printed in 2000. There is a mock-up for the book related to these images in the Project Files series. Titles assigned by photographer.

New Mexico in Black and White

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subjects of these images from 1970s trips to New Mexico include old men and women, youthful members of a gang, girls celebrating their first communion, and beauty queens. Locations - both with and without people - include natural areas such as streams and forests, as well as farms, house interiors, streets, festivals, and outdoor work locations. Specific communities include Arroyo Hondo, Chamisal, Chimayo, El Valle, Las Trampas, PeÃ±asco, Truchas, and Vallecito. The 42 gelatin silver prints are sized 11x14 (29) and 16x20 inches (13), and were printed in 1999 and 2000. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Taken over the span of roughly one year, these images dwell on aspects of life for an elderly farmer, Jacobo Romero, part of the Hispanic community of northern New Mexico. "River of Traps" refers to the river, Rio de las Trampas, which runs through this area. Romero is shown chiefly on his farm, working cattle, irrigating, and harvesting hay, and in arroyos and other natural areas where he treks to look for wood and foraged food. There are also images of his wife, his grandchildren, and friends. This project provided documentary images for a book by the same name, with text by William deBuys (1990). Some of the images also appear in a book by Robert Coles, The Old Ones of New Mexico (1973). The 30 gelatin silver prints measure 11x14 (20) and 16x20 inches (10), and were printed in 1999 and 2000. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While in New Mexico in 1979, Harris traveled to the nearby Rainbow Gathering, an annual counter-culture festival and encampment. There, he photographed men, women, and children, many of them nude, as they danced, built fires, told stories, bathed, and played instruments. The 11 gelatin silver images measure 11x14 (9) and 16x20 inches (2), and were printed in 1999-2000. Titles assigned by photographer.

did.unittitle: Snake woman, Rainbow Gathering, Alpine, Arizona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These black-and-white images were taken by Harris in May 1999 as part of an assignment to document interactions between volunteer reading tutors over the age of 55 and elementary school students in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Experience Corps is currently sponsored by the U.S. organization AARP. Most of the subjects, including volunteers, are African American. Gelatin silver prints measure 11x14 inches. Harris continued this work until 2005, with many later images taken in color. A selection of images was exhibited in the U.S. Senate Russell Building Rotunda in July 2005. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 21 gelatin silver prints of African American and white older people living on their own in the central North Carolina Piedmont communities of Durham, Cedar Grove, and other places. This commissioned project provided documentary images for a study by Robert Coles, also published in book form as Old and On Their Own (1997). Prints measure 11 x 14 inches and are matted. Printed in 1992. Titles assigned by photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 69 large (24x36 inch) pigmented color inkjet photographs taken by Alex Harris in Mobile, Alabama for a documentary book project co-authored with naturalist Edward O. Wilson, whose childhood was spent in this area of the South. The book is entitled Why We Are Here: Mobile and the Spirit of a Southern City (2012). The prints were part of an exhibit in the Mobile Museum of Art from October 2012-January 2013.

Images include portraits of Mobile citizens from various backgrounds; a football team's practices and prayer circles; women's church groups; Civil War re-enactors; street scenes; Mardi Gras events, including balls and receptions; and landscapes, including images of the Gulf of Mexico and of local and state parklands. Includes a portrait of naturalist E.O. Wilson, kneeling down to look at ants. Titles assigned by photographer.
The 69 prints measure 24x30 inches and were made on an Epson 7900 stylus pro, using Epson ultrachrome hdr inks.
The large format prints are closed to general use. A full set of 69 11x17 inch viewing copies, also pigmented color inkjet prints, are available in a separate box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains 61 17x24 inch color inkjet prints of interior views of the former home of author Reynolds Price, a friend of the photographer, taken in 2011 after Price's death. There are also 61 jpeg files of the images, and a print essay by Harris. Images include views of rooms with numerous artworks and closeups of individual art pieces in Price's house. The photographs were published in Dream of a House (2017). Titles assigned by photographer.

Artist's abstract: "My wife Margaret Sartor and I were friends with Reynolds Price as well as his relatively close neighbors. Over the years, we visited Reynolds many times in his home on Cornwallis Road in Durham. We marveled as his collections grew, particularly after he was confined to a wheelchair in 1984 until his death in 2011. That spring of 2011, I was asked to document Reynolds' home before it was dismantled. Initially I made these photographs as a collection for the Archive of Documentary Arts to accompany the Reynolds Price Archive at Rubenstein. But after making the pictures, along with Margaret I began to see connections between the man, his writing, and the collections in his home."

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The photographs are pigmented inkjet images, printed in 2017 on Canson Infinity Platine Fibre Rag (without optical brighteners), using an Epson Stylus Pro 7900 printer and Epson Ultrachrome HDR Ink.

Lectures and speaking engagements related to Harris's photographic projects and publications, including A World Unsuspected: Portraits of Southern Childhood; A New Life: Stories and Photographs from the Suburban South; and South Africa: The Cordoned Heart project, are found in their respective subseries in the Project Files Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, drafts, grant applications, research notes, photographs, printed materials, proofs, publicity, and other materials produced during Harris's work on a variety of books, conferences, exhibitions, and academic activities from the mid-1970s through 2006. Some projects are covered in considerable depth, including the following: early history of the Duke University Center for Documentary Studies; Wendy Ewald and the project that eventually became the Literacy Through Photography Program; photographer Paul Kwilecki's first book, Understandings; Harris's work with Robert Coles and Helen Levitt on her In the Street: Chalk Drawings and Messages New York City, 1938-1948; and various projects involving South African photographers (see scope notes for specific boxes). Other books and exhibitions represented in this series include: I Shall Save One Land Unvisited: Eleven Southern Photographers (1978); The Last and First Eskimos (1982); The Old Ones of New Mexico (various editions); Red White Blue and God Bless You: a Portrait of Northern New Mexico (1992); and River of Traps: a Village Life (1990). Arranged alphabetically by correspondent or topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Files consist chiefly of correspondence with several hundred authors, photographers, and staff members during the first few years of publication of the magazine DoubleTake. Recordings derive from organizational meetings and various talks by DoubleTake founders such as Robert Coles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Related materials may be found in the DoubleTake Records, 1908-1999 (bulk 1993-1999), also held in the Rubenstein Library. Materials about the magazine's founding can be found under files titled Editorial Prospectus; Whitney Ellsworth (a publishing consultant); Publication--Early Correspondence; and Quail Roost conference, and in other folders. See also the recordings in this series. Arranged alphabetically by name or topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A group of eight recordings, six of which document meetings and retreats conducted in the early 1990s to discuss creation of the magazine eventually known as DoubleTake. Two microcassettes from 1986 feature Robert Coles discussing the Center for Documentary Studies. No transcripts have been discovered, but material on the early history of the magazine is present in this collection. Several tapes may derive from the same meeting at Quail Roost Retreat in 1993, although with slight variations in labeling and dating. Tapes are arranged chronologically. "MC" denotes microcassettes, "C," audiocassettes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: [Originals closed to use. Listening copies must be made. Please consult with a reference archivist before coming to use this item.]

"#3 Quail Roost Retreat, Whitney Ellsworth, Alex Harris, et al.," 1993 May 5

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles, correspondence, grant applications, manuscripts, notes, photographic materials, printed materials, research notes, slides, tape recordings, and other documents derived from various books and related exhibitions and symposia on which Harris has worked as curator, editor, organizer, or photographer. The bulk of the materials derive from the following three books and related projects: Gertrude Blom: Bearing Witness (1984); A New Life: Stories and Photographs from the Suburban South (1997); A World Unsuspected: Portraits of Southern Childhood (1987); and from South Africa: The Cordoned Heart, (1986) a project on South African photographers documenting apartheid, conducted with Omar Badsha, Bruce Payne, Margaret Sartor, and others. Also includes the book projects Idea of Cuba, Arrivals and Departures, River of Traps, Why We Are Here, This Fabulous Loneliness, and Visions in the Dark for Aperture. There are two large sets of oral history interviews on cassette tapes in this series, deriving from Harris's work with anthropologist Blom, and from his work with South African photographers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises materials related to the book Arrivals and Departures: The Airport Pictures of Garry Winogrand, which Harris edited with Lee Friedlander. Includes correspondence; research; working files; photocopies, slides, and prints of images; along with drafts and mock-ups of the book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles, recorded interviews, correspondence, grant applications, manuscripts, research notes, card files, and other materials related to projects on anthropologist, journalist, and photographer Gertrude Duby Blom, who documented the culture and struggles of Mexican indigenous peoples such as the LacandÃ³n. Materials center around Harris's work with Blom on the book Gertrude Blom: Bearing Witness (1984) and the related exhibition at the International Center for Photography, also 1984, co-curated by Harris and Margaret Sartor. Arranged alphabetically by topic. Photos of indigenous tribes, probably from this period, are also found in Box 57.
The Rubenstein Library also holds a small collection of Blom's photographic prints of the LacandÃ³n.

South Africa: The Cordoned Heart, circa 1985-1986

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Audiocassettes and micro cassettes of interviews with many of the twenty photographers represented in the Rubenstein Library's South African Documentary Photography Collection, curated by Alex Harris during his work on the project "South Africa: The Cordoned Heart," which resulted in a book published in 1986. Interviews were conducted mainly by Alex Harris and Margaret Sartor. The tapes are mainly undated, but transcripts place them between October 1985 and July 1986. Also includes presentations by Alex Harris and Bruce Payne and others.

There are fifteen microcassettes and six audiocassettes in this group, arranged in order by last name, then by date. Unidentified tapes are at the end. Includes a set of four cassettes from a Cordoned Heart symposium, 1986. "MC" denotes microcassettes, "C," audiocassettes. Since the transcripts contain little or no reference to the tape numbering scheme, an individual transcript cannot be assumed to contain all appearances of an individual on various tapes. Transcripts are housed in the Correspondence Series under "South Africa--Transcripts."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily slides related to various projects and individuals, material related to the Hart Fellows Program, and notes and slides for talks by Harris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Syllabi, printed materials, student writings and slides, course evaluations, and other classroom materials for Harris's classes at University of North Carolina and Duke University. Arranged chronologically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: [SOME MATERIALS MAY BE RESTRICTED: Students's grades and social security numbers have been redacted in all places where they were encountered. Any similar information remaining in the files is closed to use and must be removed.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Color photographs documenting North Carolina State Fairgrounds and Durham, North Carolina urban scenes, produced by three students taking Alex Harris's course, PPS/DOCST 177S, academic year 2003-2004. Consists of nine inkjet 9x13 inch color prints and four paper-format text panels, including the introductory text panel by Harris. Some of the students's work was exhibited in 2004 at the Center for Documentary Studies under the title Sense of Place. List of titles available in the box.

scopecontent.p: Comprises proof prints and general information for various projects, including Southern Color and the Gulf Coast and New Orleans Post Katrina.
